game:apestonelantern-handbook-help-text-: Traditional Japanese garden lantern, often called 'snow-viewing lanterns'. These low, squat lanterns have wide, flat tops designed to collect snow. Snow lanterns are so named as the generous diameter of the top lid protects the fire box underneath. This attractive granite lantern is most often used in oriental water basin arrangements and needs to be chosen with care to match the proportions of the water basin used.

Traditional Japanese garden lantern, also known as buried lanterns. Oribe-Gata is the most famous design of Ikekomi-Gata. Distinctive shape with a wide, flared top and a narrower base, often decorated with geometric patterns or floral motifs. Designed to be embedded or inserted into the ground.

Traditional Japanese temple lantern. 'Okunoin' refers to the sacred area deep within a shrine, where important or hidden Buddhist statues are enshrined. Lanterns placed in these secluded areas, are called Okunoin-style lanterns. Distinctive shape with a wide, flared top with 'warabites' and a decorated base, often decorated with geometric patterns or floral motifs.

game:apepaperitem-handbook-help-text-chu:
Needs lots of cuddles, snackies and booping on the snuut.
Will gladly rest in your hands, or on top of your keyboard.
Demands total world domination, fried chicken and a clean litterbox.
game:apepaperitem-handbook-help-text-sax:
The Old Man
Overhead and ruler of the household.
